sen.j: 伏見城の戦い（ふしみじょうのたたかい）は、慶長5年（1600年）7月18日から8月1日まで行なわれた関ヶ原の戦いの前哨戦。
sen.e: The Battle of Fushimi Castle is a preliminary skirmish of the Battle of Sekigahara, which took place from July 18, to August 1, 1600.

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉の死後、次の天下人の座を狙う徳川家康は、慶長5年、度重なる上洛命令を無視した上杉景勝を公儀に反抗する逆臣として征伐すると称し、会津攻めを開始した。
sen.e: After the death of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who was seeking the post of tenkabito (the ruler of the kingdom), began invading the Aizu Domain to attack Kagekatsu UESUGI's army in 1600, claiming that UESUGI was a treacherous retainer who rebelled against the administrative authority because he had often ignored the order to go proceeding to the capital.

sen.j: すでにこの前年には、家康と並び称された親豊臣派の大老・前田利家が病死しており、五奉行の石田三成ら反家康派も失脚していた。
sen.e: One year earlier, the chief minister, Toshiie MAEDA who had belonged to the TOYOTOMI faction and been ranked with Ieyasu, had died from illness, and the anti-Ieyasu faction including Mitsunari ISHIDA, one of the five commissioners (administrative organ of feudal Japan established by Hideyoshi TOYOTOM), had been fallen from power.

sen.j: 家康は畿内の守りとして、譜代の家臣である鳥居元忠、内藤家長、松平家忠、松平近正ら1800名ほどの兵を伏見城に残すに留め、徳川軍主力を率いて会津攻めに向かう。
sen.e: Ieyasu left around 1800 soldiers, including hereditary vassals such as Mototada TORII, Ienaga NAITO, Ietada MATSUDAIRA and Chikamasa MATSUDAIRA, in the Fushimi Castle to protect the territories in the vicinity of the capital, and proceeded to the Aizu Domain with the leading soldiers of Tokugawa's army.

sen.j: 畿内に軍事的空白が生まれたことを好機と見た石田三成は、毛利輝元、宇喜多秀家、大谷吉継ら反家康派の諸大名を糾合して挙兵し、7月17日、家康が大坂城西の丸に残していた留守居役を追放して、家康に対する13か条の弾劾状を叩きつけた。
sen.e: Mitsunari ISHIDA, who saw the military space within the territories in the vicinity of the capital as an opportunity, massed various anti-Ieyasu Daimyo, such as Terumoto MORI, Hideie UKITA and Yoshitsugu OTANI, to raise an army, and on July 17, purged the Rusuiyaku (persons representing the master during his absence), who remained in the western citadel of Osaka Castle on orders from Ieyasu, and then thrust 13 articles of impeachment at Ieyasu.

sen.j: 翌7月18日には、西軍総大将である毛利輝元の名で、伏見城の守将・鳥居元忠に対して伏見城を明け渡すように命令が出された。
sen.e: On the next day, July 18, an order to surrender Fushimi Castle was issued to the defense general, Mototada TORII, by the name of Terumoto MORI, the commander-in-chief of the western army.
On the next day, July 18, an order to surrender Fushimi Castle was issued to the defending general, Mototada TORII, in the name of Terumoto MORI, the commander-in-chief of the western army.
On the next day, July 18, an order to surrender Fushimi-jo Castle was issued to the defending general, Mototada TORII, in the name of Terumoto MORI, the commander-in-chief of the western army.

sen.j: 家康に死守を命じられていた元忠はこれを拒絶し、西軍は大挙して伏見城を包囲、攻撃を開始した。
sen.e: Mototada, who had been told to defend to the death by Ieyasu, refused this order, and the western army surrounded Fushimi Castle in full force and started attacking.

sen.j: 伏見城攻めの総大将は宇喜多秀家、副将は小早川秀秋で、その他に毛利秀元、吉川広家、小西行長、島津義弘、長宗我部盛親、長束正家、鍋島勝茂などが攻城側に参加し、総勢4万人の大軍であった。
sen.e: The army, which was attacking Fushimi Castle, had a total of 40,000 soldiers lead by Hideie UKITA, the commander-in-chief, and Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA, the adjutant general, with other members including Hidemoto MORI, Hiroie YOSHIKAWA, Yukinaga KONISHI, Yoshihiro SHIMAZU, Morichika CHOSOKABE, Masaie NAGATSUKA and Katsushige NABESHIMA.

sen.j: これに対して、守備軍は鳥居元忠を総大将とした1800人であった。
sen.e: The defensive force, on the other hand, had 1,800 soldiers lead by Mototada TORII, the commander-in-chief.

sen.j: 伏見城は豊臣秀吉が築き上げた巨郭であったが、兵力差から考えれば短時日で決着するはずの戦いであったが、攻城側は苦戦を強いられた。
sen.e: Fushimi Castle was a huge building built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and the battle should have come to an end in a short period of time given the difference in force size; however, the attacking force was facing a hard time against the defensive force.

sen.j: 城将の鳥居元忠とその兵達が予想外の奮戦を見せ、また包囲軍の内部にも三成らに強制的に西軍として与させられた者がおり、戦意が上がらなったなどの要因があったためとされる。
sen.e: The reasons for this include the facts that Mototada TORII, the commander-in-chief, and his troop fought up unexpectedly against the attacking force and that the besieging army had some soldiers who had been forcibly asked to join the western army by Mitsunari and some other people and thus had little will to fight.

The reasons for this include the facts that Mototada TORII, the commander-in-chief, and his troop fought back unexpectedly against the attacking force and that the besieging army had some soldiers who had been forced to join the western army by Mitsunari and some other people and thus had little will to fight.

sen.j: 状況を打開するため、島津義弘は配下の長束正家に伏見城内にいた甲賀衆の妻子一族を捕縛させ、内通しなければ家族を磔にすると脅迫することを命じた。
sen.e: To break down such a situation, Yoshihiro SHIMAZU had his subordinate, Masaie NAGATSUKA, take up the wives and children of the Koga group in the castle and ordered him to threaten the Koga group by saying that they would crucify the wives and children unless they would surrender the castle.

sen.e: Because Masaie was the feudal lord of Minakuchi-okayama Castle in Omi Province, he had close ties to Koga people, and there were some people of Koga County other than people of the Iga Province of the Tokugawa clan in the castle.

sen.j: 甲賀衆はこの脅迫に応じ、伏見城内に火事を起こした。
sen.e: The Koga group yielded to the threat and set the castle alight.

sen.j: この裏切りによって支えきれなくなった元忠は8月1日に討死し、伏見城はようやく落城した。
sen.e: Mototada, who was cornered by this betrayal, died in battle on August 1 and Fushimi Castle was finally surrendered.

sen.e: The western army's delay in occupation of Fushimi Castle, which was expected to complete within a few days but actually took 10 days, is said to be a factor in the delay of attacking Mino Province and Ise Province to which the western army was going to proceed after Fushimi Castle.
